sn56.31:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī in a rosewood forest.
sn56.31:1.2: Then the Buddha picked up a few rosewood leaves in his hand and addressed the mendicants:
sn56.31:1.5: the few leaves in my hand, or those in the forest above me?”
sn56.31:1.6: “Sir, the few leaves in your hand are a tiny amount.
sn56.31:1.7: There are far more leaves in the forest above.”
sn56.31:1.8: “In the same way, there is much more that I have directly known but have not explained to you. What I have explained is a tiny amount.
sn56.31:1.9: And why haven’t I explained it?
sn56.31:1.10: Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
sn56.31:1.11: That’s why I haven’t explained it.
sn56.31:2.2: I have explained: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
sn56.31:3.1: And why have I explained this?
sn56.31:3.2: Because it’s beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
sn56.31:4.1: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
